Core Concepts

Git‚Äôs Mental Model

Understanding Git requires understanding a few key concepts. Let‚Äôs build your mental model step by step.

The Repository (Repo)

A repository is a folder that Git tracks. It contains: - Your project files (code, docs, images, etc.) - A hidden .git folder with all the history and metadata

Think of a repo as a project with a complete memory of everything that‚Äôs ever happened to it.

my-project/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .git/           # Git's database (hidden folder)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index.js
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json

Local vs Remote Repositories

Type Location Purpose
Local repo On your computer Where you work
Remote repo On GitHub Where you collaborate and back up

You typically work locally and push changes to the remote. You pull others‚Äô changes from the remote.

Commits: Snapshots of Your Work

A commit is a snapshot of your entire project at a specific moment. Each commit includes:

  • ‚úÖ The state of all files
  • ‚úÖ Who made the change
  • ‚úÖ When they made it
  • ‚úÖ Why they made it (commit message)
  • ‚úÖ A unique ID (SHA hash like a3f2b91)

Commits are immutable ‚Äî once created, they never change. This creates an unbreakable chain of history.

Commit History (like a timeline):

a3f2b91 - "Add user login feature" (Dec 9, 2025)
    ‚Üë
b7c8d42 - "Fix homepage typo" (Dec 8, 2025)
    ‚Üë
c9e1f53 - "Initial project setup" (Dec 7, 2025)

Writing Good Commit Messages

‚ùå Bad ‚úÖ Good
‚ÄúFix‚Äù ‚ÄúFix null pointer exception in user authentication‚Äù
‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù ‚ÄúUpdate homepage hero image for Q4 campaign‚Äù
‚ÄúWIP‚Äù ‚ÄúAdd basic validation to contact form (WIP)‚Äù
‚Äústuff‚Äù ‚ÄúRefactor database queries for better performance‚Äù

Format tip:

[type]: Short summary (50 chars or less)

Longer description if needed. Explain WHY, not just WHAT.
Reference issue numbers: Fixes #123

The Three States of Files

Git files exist in three states:

  1. Modified: You changed the file, but haven‚Äôt told Git yet
  2. Staged: You marked the file to be included in the next commit
  3. Committed: The file is safely stored in Git‚Äôs database

Think of staging as packing a box before shipping it. You choose what goes in.

Working Directory  ‚Üí  Staging Area  ‚Üí  Repository
(modified files)     (files ready      (committed
                     to commit)         snapshots)

[edit file]       ‚Üí  [git add]     ‚Üí  [git commit]

Why a Staging Area?

The staging area lets you: - Be selective: Commit only some changes, not everything - Review before committing: Double-check what you‚Äôre about to save - Create focused commits: One logical change per commit

Branches: Parallel Universes for Your Code

A branch is an independent line of development. Branches let you: - Work on features without affecting the main codebase - Experiment safely - Collaborate without conflicts - Organize work by feature, bug fix, or team

main:      A---B---C---------F
                \           /
feature:         D---E-----

Key Branch Types

Branch Type Purpose Example Name
main Primary branch, production-ready main
Feature New functionality feature/user-auth
Bug fix Fix issues fix/login-error
Release Prepare releases release/v2.0
Hotfix Emergency production fixes hotfix/security-patch

Creating and Switching Branches

# Create a new branch
git branch feature/new-feature

# Switch to that branch
git checkout feature/new-feature

# Or do both in one command
git checkout -b feature/new-feature

Merging: Combining Branches

Merging brings changes from one branch into another. Git is smart ‚Äî it automatically combines changes unless there‚Äôs a conflict.

Before merge:
main:    A---B---C
              \
feature:       D---E

After merge:
main:    A---B---C-------F
              \         /
feature:       D---E----

Types of Merges

Fast-Forward Merge ‚Äî When main hasn‚Äôt changed since you branched:

Before:  main: A---B
                   \
         feature:   C---D

After:   main: A---B---C---D (fast-forwarded)

Three-Way Merge ‚Äî When both branches have new commits:

Before:  main:    A---B---E
                      \
         feature:      C---D

After:   main:    A---B---E---F (merge commit)
                      \      /
         feature:      C---D-

Merge Conflicts: When Git Needs Help

A conflict happens when: 1. Two people edit the same line of the same file 2. Git can‚Äôt automatically decide which change to keep

Don‚Äôt panic! Conflicts are normal and solvable.

What Conflicts Look Like

When you try to merge and there‚Äôs a conflict, Git marks the file:

function greeting() {
<<<<<<< HEAD
  return "Hello, World!";
=======
  return "Hi there!";
>>>>>>> feature/new-greeting
}
  • <<<<<<< HEAD ‚Äî Your current branch‚Äôs version
  • ======= ‚Äî Separator
  • >>>>>>> feature/new-greeting ‚Äî Incoming branch‚Äôs version

Resolving Conflicts

  1. Open the conflicted file
  2. Choose which change to keep (or combine them)
  3. Remove the conflict markers
  4. Stage the resolved file: git add filename
  5. Complete the merge: git commit

Resolved version:

function greeting() {
  return "Hello there!";  // Combined both versions
}

The Git Workflow

Putting it all together, here‚Äôs a typical workflow:

1. Pull latest changes        git pull origin main
2. Create feature branch      git checkout -b feature/my-feature
3. Make changes              [edit files]
4. Stage changes             git add .
5. Commit changes            git commit -m "Add feature"
6. Push to remote            git push origin feature/my-feature
7. Create Pull Request       [on GitHub]
8. Review & Merge            [on GitHub]
9. Delete branch             git branch -d feature/my-feature

Visual Summary

üé® Key Concepts at a Glance
**Repository**: Your project folder + Git history **Commit**: A snapshot with who/what/when/why **Branch**: Parallel line of development **Merge**: Combining branches together **Remote**: GitHub copy for collaboration **Conflict**: When Git needs human help to merge

Coming Up Next

Now that you understand the concepts, let‚Äôs put them into practice with a hands-on walkthrough of creating a repository, making commits, and pushing to GitHub.
